translated: Composed by Venerable Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

The dharmas of ordinary beings are subsumed under eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and the entire proclivities of the desire realm and form realm increase them.

The dharmas not shared by ordinary beings are subsumed under eleven elements, ten sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by ten knowledges, are cognized by four consciousnesses, and the proclivities of the three realms that are universally eliminated and those eliminated by cultivation increase them.

The dharmas shared by ordinary beings are subsumed under eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and all proclivities increase them.

The dharmas not shared by ordinary beings are subsumed under eleven elements, ten sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by ten knowledges, are cognized by four consciousnesses, and the proclivities of the three realms that are universally eliminated and those eliminated by cultivation increase them.

The dharmas of concentration are categorized as five elements, four sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and are discerned by three consciousnesses. The entanglements to be eliminated by cultivation in the realm of desire and the universal [contaminants] of the three realms increase [in them].

The dharmas not of concentration are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges excluding the knowledge of the path, and are discerned by six consciousnesses. All the entanglements increase [in them].

The dharmas that accord with heat are categorized as ten elements, four sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, and are discerned by three consciousnesses. All the entanglements increase [in them].

The dharmas that do not accord with heat are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges, and are discerned by six consciousnesses. The universal [contaminants] of the three realms and the entanglements eliminated by the path of cultivation increase [in them].

The dharmas that are faculties are categorized as thirteen elements, seven sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and are discerned by one consciousness. All the entanglements increase [in them].

The dharmas that are not faculties are categorized as six elements, six sense bases, and three aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges, and are discerned by six consciousnesses. All the entanglements increase [in them].

The dharmas included in the noble truths are subsumed under eighteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges and cognized by six consciousnesses, and all proclivities increase them.

The dharmas not included in the noble truths are subsumed under one sense field, one sense base, and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by one knowledge, namely conventional knowledge, and cognized by one consciousness, and proclivities do not increase them.

The dharmas that coexist are subsumed under eighteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and cognized by six consciousnesses, and all proclivities increase them.

The dharmas that do not coexist are subsumed under one sense field, one sense base, and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of the path, and cognized by one consciousness, and proclivities do not increase them.

The associated dharmas are subsumed under eight sense fields, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and cognized by one consciousness, and all proclivities increase them.

The dharmas not associated with mind are categorized as eleven sense bases, eleven sense fields, and two aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. The proclivities of the three realms that take impure dharmas as objects increase in them.

Dharmas that are results are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges and discerned by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase in them.

Dharmas that are not results are not categorized as a sense base or an aggregate. They are known by one knowledge, i.e., conventional knowledge, and discerned by one consciousness, i.e., the mental consciousness. Proclivities do not increase in them.

Dharmas that have results are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase in them.

Dharmas that do not have results are not categorized as a sense base or an aggregate. They are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the origin, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness, i.e., the mental consciousness. Proclivities do not increase in them.

The dharmas that are karmic results are categorized as seventeen sense bases, eleven sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by five consciousnesses. The universal and particular propensities of the three realms are all associated with them.

The dharmas that are not karmic results are categorized as eighteen sense bases, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All propensities are associated with them.

The dharmas that have karmic results are categorized as ten sense bases, four sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by three consciousnesses. All those of the realm of desire and the universal and particular propensities of the realms of form and of non-form are all associated with them.

The dharmas that do not have karmic results are categorized as eighteen sense bases, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All those of the two categories of the realm of desire and of the realms of form and of non-form, and the universal propensities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the origination of suffering and of the path are all associated with them.

The dharmas that are conditions as cause are categorized as eighteen sense bases, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All propensities are associated with them.

The dharmas that are not conditions are not included in the aggregates, sense bases, or elements, are not known by any of the knowledges, are not cognized by any of the consciousnesses, and are not increased by any of the latent afflictions, because such dharmas cannot be obtained.

The dharmas that are conditions are included in eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and are increased by all the latent afflictions.

The dharmas that are not conditions are included in one element and one sense base but are not included in any aggregates, are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by one kind of consciousness, and are not increased by any of the latent afflictions.

The dharmas that are separated are included in five elements, four sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by ten knowledges, are cognized by three kinds of consciousness, and are increased by the universal and those eliminated by the path of cultivation in the three realms.

The dharmas that are not separated are included in eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by six consciousnesses, and are increased by all the latent afflictions.

The dharmas that are dissociated [from thought] are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, the twelve sense bases, and the five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and are discerned by the six consciousnesses. All of the proclivities increase them.

The dharmas that are not dissociated are categorized as one sense base and one sense field, and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the origin, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness and are not increased by any of the proclivities.

The dharmas that are continuous are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, the twelve sense bases, and the five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and are discerned by the six consciousnesses. All of the proclivities increase them.

The dharmas that are not continuous are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, the twelve sense bases, and the five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges and are discerned by the six consciousnesses. All of the proclivities increase them.
The dharmas that are both continuous and not continuous are also like this.

The good dharmas are categorized as ten sense bases, four sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges and are discerned by three consciousnesses. The proclivities of the three realms that are eliminated by insight and those that are eliminated by cultivation increase them.

Unwholesome dharmas are categorized as ten elements, four sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by three consciousnesses. All proclivities of the desire realm increase upon them.

Indeterminate dharmas are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by six consciousnesses. All of the desire realm, the two parts of the form realm and the formless realm, and the universal proclivities that are eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the origination of suffering increase upon them.

Dharmas of those still learning and of those no longer learning are categorized as three elements, two sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the elimination of the contaminants, the knowledge of nonproduction, the knowledge of destruction, and the knowledge of nonarising. They are perceived by one consciousness. They are not increased by any proclivities.

Dharmas of neither those still learning nor of those no longer learning are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase upon them.

Dharmas eliminated by the path of insight are categorized as three elements, two sense spheres, and four aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by one consciousness. All proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of the origination of suffering increase upon them.

Dharmas that are eliminated by cultivation are subsumed under eighteen sense fields, twelve entrances, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All proclivities of the three realms that are eliminated by cultivation and the universal proclivities increase in them.

Dharmas that are not eliminated are subsumed under three realms, two entrances, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the cause of suffering. They are discerned by one consciousness. No proclivities increase in them.ğŸ”½Dharmas that are the cause of what is eliminated by seeing are subsumed under eighteen sense fields, twelve entrances, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase in them.

Dharmas that are the cause of what is eliminated by cultivation are subsumed under eighteen sense fields, twelve entrances, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All proclivities of the three realms that are eliminated by cultivation and the universal proclivities increase in them.

Dharmas that are the cause of what is not eliminated are subsumed under three realms, two entrances, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause of suffering, and the knowledge of cessation. They are discerned by one consciousness. No proclivities increase in them.

The dharmas with form and resistance are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by two consciousnesses. They are increased by the contaminants of the realm of desire and the realm of form, and by the contaminants that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

The dharmas without form and with resistance are categorized as nine realms, nine sense bases, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by five consciousnesses. They are increased by the contaminants of the realm of desire and the realm of form, and by the contaminants that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

The dharmas without form and without resistance are categorized as eight realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are perceived by one consciousness. They are increased by all contaminants.

The dharmas that are retribution are categorized as seventeen realms, eleven sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by five consciousnesses. They are increased by the contaminants of the three realms that are universally good and by the contaminants that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

The factors that are karmic results and the factors that are not karmic results are categorized as ten elements, four spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by three consciousnesses. The entanglements of the entire realm of desire and the universal and partially-fixed entanglements of the realms of form and of non-form are all able to disturb them.

The factors that are neither karmic results nor the factors that are not karmic results are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by ten knowledges. They are perceived by six consciousnesses. The entanglements of the entire realms of form and of non-form, the two parts of the entanglements of the realm of desire, and the universal entanglements that are eliminated by the path of insight are all able to disturb them.

The inferior factors are categorized as ten elements, four spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by three consciousnesses. All entanglements are able to disturb them.

The middling factors are categorized as eighteen elements, twelve spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are perceived by six consciousnesses. The universal entanglements of the three realms and the entanglements eliminated by the path of cultivation are all able to disturb them.

The superior factors are categorized as three elements, two spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the cause of suffering. They are perceived by one consciousness. No entanglements are able to disturb them.

The small dharmas and the great dharmas are included in the eighteen realms, twelve fields, and five aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by six consciousnesses; and they are associated with all the propensities.ğŸ”½The immeasurable dharmas, agreeable dharmas, disagreeable dharmas, and neither agreeable nor disagreeable dharmas are included in the eighteen realms, twelve fields, and five aggregates; they are known by ten knowledges; they are cognized by six consciousnesses; and they are associated with all the propensities.

Dharmas associated with pleasure are included in eight realms, two fields, and three aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and they are associated with all the propensities of the form realm, except for doubt and ignorance associated with it that have desire as their object, and all the propensities of the desire realm. Dharmas associated with suffering are included in eight realms, two fields, and three aggregates; they are known by seven knowledges except for the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and they are associated with all the propensities of the desire realm.

The dharmas associated with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling are included in eight sense bases, two sense fields, and three aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and they are associated with all the latent defilements.

The dharmas that arise together, abide together, and cease together are included in eighteen sense bases, twelve sense fields, and five aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by six consciousnesses; and they are associated with all the latent defilements.

The dharmas that do not arise together, do not abide together, and do not cease together are not included in any sense bases, sense fields, or aggregates; they are known by six knowledges: the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of the path; they are cognized by one consciousness; and they are not associated with any latent defilements.ğŸ”½The dharmas that arise together with the mind are included in eleven sense bases, eleven sense fields, and four aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by six consciousnesses; and they are associated with all the latent defilements.

The dharmas that abide together with the mind are included in one sense base, one sense field, and four aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and they are associated with all the latent defilements.

The dharmas that are born, abide, and perish together with the mind are categorized as the ten sense bases and four aggregates, are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, are perceived by five consciousnesses, and increase with all the latent afflictions.

The dharmas that are not born, do not abide, and do not perish together with the mind are categorized as the eighteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and three aggregates, are known by ten knowledges, are perceived by six consciousnesses, and increase with all the latent afflictions.

The desire realm is categorized as ten sense bases, four sense fields, and five aggregates, is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the class, cessation, and path, is perceived by three consciousnesses, and increases with the latent afflictions that are the objects of the desire realm.

The realm of anger is also like this.ğŸ”½The realm of harm is categorized as five sense bases, four sense fields, and five aggregates, is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the class, cessation, and path, is perceived by three consciousnesses, and increases with the universal and those that are to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.

The realm of renunciation is categorized as ten sense bases, four sense fields, and five aggregates, is known by ten knowledges, is perceived by three consciousnesses, and increases with the universal and those that are to be eliminated by cultivation in the three realms.

The realm of non-hatred and the realm of non-harm are categorized as ten realms, four spheres, and five aggregates. Nine knowledges know them, excluding the knowledge of cessation. Three consciousnesses are cognized. The universal contaminants and the contaminants to be eliminated by cultivation increase in them.

The desire realm is categorized as eighteen realms, twelve spheres, and five aggregates. Seven knowledges know it, excluding the knowledge of subsequent cognition, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. Six consciousnesses cognize it. All contaminants of the desire realm increase in it.

The form realm is categorized as fourteen realms, ten spheres, and five aggregates. Seven knowledges know it, excluding the knowledge of the dharma, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. Four consciousnesses cognize it. All contaminants of the form realm increase in it.

The formless realm is categorized as three realms, two spheres, and four aggregates. Six knowledges know it, excluding the knowledge of the dharma, the knowledge of another's mind, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. One consciousness cognizes it. All contaminants of the formless realm increase in it.

The desire realm and the form realm are called the form realm. They are categorized as eighteen realms, twelve spheres, and five aggregates. Eight knowledges know them, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. Six consciousnesses cognize them. All contaminants of the desire and form realms increase in them.

The four formless realms are called the formless realm. They are categorized as the two realms of the formless and the four aggregates. They are known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the mind of another, the knowledge of elimination, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness and are increased by all the propensities of the formless realm.

Extinction through discrimination and non-extinction are called the realm of extinction. They are categorized as one realm and one base and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the mind of another, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness and are neither propensities nor that which increases propensities.

Next, all material dharmas are generally called the realm of form. They are categorized as eleven realms, eleven bases, and one aggregate. They are known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the mind of another and the knowledge of elimination. They are discerned by six consciousnesses and are increased by the universal and those eliminated by the path of cultivation of the realms of desire and form.

Excluding extinction through discrimination and non-extinction, the remaining non-material dharmas are generally called the formless realm. They are categorized as eight realms, two bases, and four aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of elimination. They are discerned by one consciousness and are increased by all the propensities.
Extinction through discrimination and non-extinction are generally called the realm of extinction, as explained above.

As for the existence of desire, it is categorized as the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by six consciousnesses and is increased by all the latent afflictions of the desire realm.

As for the existence of form, it is categorized as fourteen elements, ten sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the knowable, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by four consciousnesses and is increased by all the latent afflictions of the form realm.

As for the existence of the formless, it is categorized as three elements, two sense bases, and four aggregates. It is known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of the knowable, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness and is increased by all the latent afflictions of the formless realm.ğŸ”½As for the outflows of desire, they are categorized as one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness and are increased by all the latent afflictions of the desire realm.

As for the outflows of existence, they are categorized as one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the knowable, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness and are increased by all the latent afflictions of the form and formless realms.

The outflows of ignorance are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. Eight knowledges know them, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. One consciousness is aware of them, excluding the ignorance that is not a condition for the outflows. All proclivities increase them.

The three times and the three statements are categorized as the eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. Nine knowledges know them, excluding the knowledge of cessation. Six consciousnesses are aware of them. All proclivities increase them.

The desire realm is suffering because of the suffering of suffering. It is categorized as the eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. Seven knowledges know it, excluding the knowledge of subsequently acquired awareness, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. Six consciousnesses are aware of it. All proclivities of the desire realm increase it.

The form realm is suffering because of the suffering of change. It is categorized as fourteen realms, ten sense bases, and five aggregates. Seven knowledges know it, excluding the knowledge of the dharma, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. Four consciousnesses are aware of it. All proclivities of the form realm increase it.

As for the formless realm being suffering due to the suffering of conditioned existence, it is included in the three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates, known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, cognized by one consciousness, and all proclivities increase in it.ğŸ”½Next, as for disagreeable activities being suffering due to the suffering of suffering, agreeable activities being suffering due to the suffering of change, and neither disagreeable nor agreeable activities being suffering due to the suffering of conditioned existence, they are all included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, cognized by six consciousnesses, and all proclivities increase in them.

Next, as for painful feeling being suffering due to the suffering of suffering, it is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate, known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the elimination of contaminants, the knowledge of non-arising, and the knowledge of the path, cognized by one consciousness, and all proclivities of the desire realm increase in it.

The pleasant feeling that is suffering due to the suffering of change is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the form realm, except for doubt and ignorance associated with it that have the desire realm as their object, and all proclivities of the desire realm, increase in it.

The neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling that is suffering due to the suffering of formations is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase in it.ğŸ”½Dharmas with initial and sustained thought are included in eight elements, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the desire and form realms increase in them.

Dharmas without initial thought but with sustained thought only are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the desire and form realms increase in them.

The dharmas without initial and sustained thought are categorized as thirteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by ten of the knowledges. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. The proclivities of the realm of form and of the formless realm that take the impure as object increase in them.

The stage with initial and sustained thought is categorized as the eighteen sense fields, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase in it.

The stage without initial thought but only sustained thought is categorized as three sense fields, two sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. The universal proclivities of the realm of form and those that are eliminated by the path of cultivation increase in it.

The stage without initial or sustained thought is categorized as eleven sense fields, ten sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by four consciousnesses. All proclivities of the realm of form and of the formless realm increase in it.

Bodily action is categorized as two sense bases and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of the thoughts of others and the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by two consciousnesses. The universal proclivities of the realm of desire and of the realm of form and those that are eliminated by the path of cultivation increase in it.
The same applies to verbal action.

Mental action is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. All latent afflictions increase along with it.

Wholesome action is included in three elements, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. The universal contaminants of the three realms and those contaminants to be eliminated by cultivation increase along with it.

Unwholesome action is included in three elements, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges except for the knowledge of the classes, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. All latent afflictions of the desire realm increase along with it.

Indeterminate action is included in three elements, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. All of the form and formless realms, the three categories of the desire realm, and the universal contaminants eliminated by the path of seeing increase along with it.

Learned action and unlearned action are included in one element, one sense base, and two aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges except for the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. They do not increase along with latent afflictions.

Non-learner and non-non-learner karma is categorized as three realms, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. All proclivities increase it.

Karma that is to be eliminated by the path of insight is categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities that are to be eliminated by the path of insight in the three realms increase it.

Karma that is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation is categorized as three realms, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. All proclivities that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the three realms and all universal proclivities increase it.

Karma that is not to be eliminated is categorized as one realm, one sense base, and two aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is not increased by proclivities.

Karma to be experienced in the present life, karma to be experienced in the next life, and karma to be experienced in a subsequent lifetime are included in three realms, three sense bases, and two aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by three consciousnesses. All proclivities of the desire realm, and the pervasive and those eliminated by cultivation in the form and formless realms increase them.

Karma to be experienced as pleasant feeling is included in three realms, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. The pervasive and those eliminated by cultivation in the desire and form realms increase it.

Karma to be experienced as painful feeling is included in three realms, three sense bases, and two aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges except for the knowledge of the classes, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by three consciousnesses. All proclivities of the desire realm increase it.

Karma to be experienced as neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is included in one realm, one sense base, and two aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges except for the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The pervasive and those eliminated by cultivation in the form and formless realms increase it.

The application of mindfulness to the body is included in eleven sense bases, eleven sense fields, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of others' minds and the knowledge of the cessation of suffering. It is cognized by six consciousnesses, and the latent tendencies to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the desire and form realms and the universal [defilements] increase [in it].

The application of mindfulness to feelings is included in one sense base, one sense field, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering. It is cognized by one consciousness, and all latent tendencies increase [in it].

The application of mindfulness to the mind is included in seven sense bases, one sense field, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering. It is cognized by one consciousness, and all latent tendencies increase [in it].

The application of mindfulness to dharmas is included in one sense base, one sense field, and two aggregates. It is known by ten knowledges. It is cognized by one consciousness, and all latent tendencies increase [in it].

Furthermore, the wholesome contaminated and uncontaminated paths that arise from the predominance of the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas are included in three sense bases, two sense fields, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the cessation of suffering. They are cognized by one consciousness. The universal [defilements] of the three realms and the latent tendencies to be eliminated by the path of cultivation increase [in them].

Moreover, the wholesome contaminated and uncontaminated wisdom that arises in relation to the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas, is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation, and is cognized by one consciousness. The latent tendencies of the three realms that are eliminated by insight and cultivation increase in it.

The four right efforts and the four bases of supernatural power are included in three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation, and are cognized by one consciousness. The latent tendencies of the three realms that are eliminated by insight and cultivation increase in them.

The four meditations are included in three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation, and are cognized by one consciousness. The universal and eliminated by cultivation latent tendencies of the form realm increase in them.

The noble truths of suffering and origination are included in eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, and are cognized by six consciousnesses. All latent tendencies increase in them.

The noble truth of cessation is included in one realm, one sense base, and is not included in any aggregate. It is known by six knowledges except for the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. Latent tendencies do not increase in it.

The noble truth of the path is included in the three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledges of suffering, origination, and cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. No proclivities increase along with it.ğŸ”½The four immeasurables are included in the three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledges of dharmas, cessation, and path. They are cognized by one consciousness. The proclivities of the form realm, universal [proclivities], and those eliminated by cultivation increase along with them.

The sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, and the sphere of nothingness are included in the three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledges of dharmas, others' minds, and cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the formless realm increase along with them.

The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is included in the three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. It is known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledges of dharmas, others' minds, cessation, and path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the formless realm increase along with it.

The four noble lineages are included in the three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness. The proclivities of the three realms, universal [proclivities], and those eliminated by cultivation increase along with them.

The four conditioned fruits of asceticism are categorized as three realms, two sense spheres, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by one consciousness and are neither associated with nor increase according to the proclivities.

The four unconditioned fruits of asceticism are categorized as one realm, one sense sphere, and are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness and are neither associated with nor increase according to the proclivities.ğŸ”½The knowledge of dharmas is categorized as one realm, one sense sphere, and one aggregate. It is known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of subsequent cognition, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness and is neither associated with nor increases according to the proclivities.

The knowledge of subsequent cognition is categorized as one realm, one sense sphere, and one aggregate. It is known by six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness and is neither associated with nor increases according to the proclivities.

The knowledge of othersâ€™ minds is categorized as one realm, one sense sphere, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. It is associated with the proclivities of the realm of form and those that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation.

The conventional cognition is categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight cognitions, excluding the cognition of cessation and the cognition of the path. It is discerned by one consciousness, excluding the impure views and all the proclivities and latent tendencies that increase.

The cognition of suffering, the cognition of the cause, the cognition of cessation, and the cognition of the path are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven cognitions, excluding the cognition of suffering, the cognition of the cause, and the cognition of cessation. They are discerned by one consciousness. They are not proclivities or that which increases proclivities.

The unobstructed cognition of dharmas is categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight cognitions, excluding the cognition of cessation and the cognition of the path. It is discerned by one consciousness. It is increased by the proclivities and latent tendencies of the desire and form realms that are eliminated by cultivation.
The unobstructed cognition of expression is also like this.

The unobstructed cognition of meaning is categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine cognitions, excluding the cognition of cessation. It is discerned by one consciousness. It is increased by the proclivities and latent tendencies of the three realms that are eliminated by cultivation.
The unobstructed cognition of eloquence is also like this.

The conditions are categorized as eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine cognitions, excluding the cognition of cessation. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. They are increased by all the proclivities.

The condition as similar and immediately antecedent is included in eight elements, two spheres, and four aggregates; it is known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; it is discerned by one consciousness; and it is associated with all the permeating factors.

The condition as object and the dominant condition are included in eighteen elements, twelve spheres, and five aggregates; they are known by ten knowledges; they are discerned by six consciousnesses; and they are associated with all the permeating factors.

The food of morsel eating is included in three elements, three spheres, and one aggregate; it is known by six knowledges, except for the knowledge of the class, the knowledge of another's mind, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path; it is discerned by four consciousnesses; and it is associated with the permeating factors of the desire realm and those eliminated by cultivation.ğŸ”½The food of contact and the food of volition are included in one element, one sphere, and one aggregate; they are known by eight knowledges, except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path; they are discerned by one consciousness; and they are associated with all the permeating factors.

The food of consciousness is included in seven elements, one sphere, and one aggregate; it is known by eight knowledges, except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path; it is discerned by one consciousness; and it is associated with all the permeating factors.

The flood of desire is comprised of one element, one sphere, and one aggregate; it is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path; it is cognized by one consciousness; and all the proclivities of the desire realm increase it.

The flood of existence is comprised of one element, one sphere, and one aggregate; it is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the law, the knowledge of the destruction, and the knowledge of the path; it is cognized by one consciousness; and all the proclivities of the form realm and the formless realm increase it.

The flood of views is comprised of one element, one sphere, and one aggregate; it is known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path; it is cognized by one consciousness; and the proclivities that are eliminated by seeing the three realms, those that have objects to be abandoned by seeing, and ignorance that has pure objects increase it.

The flood of ignorance is comprised of one element, one sphere, and one aggregate; it is known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path; it is cognized by one consciousness; and all the proclivities, excluding ignorance that has pure objects, increase it.
The four graspings are also like this.

The grasping of desire is comprised of one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the desire realm increase it.ğŸ”½The grasping of views is comprised of one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The impure influences of the three realms that are eliminated by the path of insight, and the impure influences of the view of the aggregates as pure, and the ignorance associated with the view of the aggregates as pure, increase it.

The grasping of morality and vows is comprised of one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of suffering of the three realms, and the universal proclivities eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of origination, and the impure influences of the three realms that are eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of the path, increase it.

The grasping of self-theory is comprised of one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the truth of the Dharma, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the form and formless realms increase it.

The past, future, and present dharmas are subsumed under the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation, and are cognized by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase them.

Dharmas that are neither past, future, nor present are subsumed under one element and one sense base, but are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness and are not increased by any proclivities.

Dharmas bound to the desire realm are subsumed under the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the class, cessation, and the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. All proclivities of the desire realm increase them.

Dharmas bound to the form realm are subsumed under fourteen elements, ten sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the dharma, cessation, and the path. They are cognized by four consciousnesses. All proclivities of the form realm increase them.

Dharmas bound to the formless realm are subsumed under three elements, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of the dharma, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities of the formless realm increase them.

The dharmas not bound to the realms are categorized as three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledges of suffering and of origin. They are cognized by one consciousness. No proclivities increase with them.

Dharmas that are causes of the wholesome are categorized as eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. The proclivities of the three realms that are universally active and those that are objects to be eliminated by the path of cultivation increase with them.

Dharmas that are causes of the unwholesome are categorized as eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the class, cessation, and the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. All proclivities of the realm of desire increase with them.

Dharmas that are causes of the indeterminate are categorized as eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the path. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. All proclivities increase with them.

Dharmas that are not causes of the wholesome, not causes of the unwholesome, and not causes of the indeterminate are not categorized as any realms, sense bases, or aggregates. They are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of the thoughts of others, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the origin, and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. No proclivities increase with them.

The dharmas that are objects of perception are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and the proclivities of the three realms that have a real object increase in them.

The dharmas that are not objects of perception are included in eight sense bases, two sense bases, and four aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and all proclivities increase in them.

The dharmas that are objects of perception and are also not objects of perception are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation; they are cognized by one consciousness; and the proclivities of the three realms that have a real object increase in them.

The dharmas that are neither objects of perception nor not objects of perception are included in eleven sense bases, eleven sense bases, and two aggregates; they are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds; they are cognized by six consciousnesses; and the proclivities of the three realms that have a real object increase in them.

The form aggregate is included in eleven sense bases, eleven sense bases, and one aggregate; it is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of the cessation of suffering and the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds; it is cognized by six consciousnesses; and the proclivities of the desire realm and form realm that are universal and those eliminated by the path of cultivation increase in it.

The aggregate of feeling is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.
The aggregate of perception and the aggregate of volitional formations are also like this.

The aggregate of consciousness is included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.

The material aggregate of grasping is included in eleven elements, eleven sense bases, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, and the knowledge of others' minds. It is cognized by six consciousnesses. The proclivities of the desire realm and form realm that are to be eliminated by cultivation increase it.

The aggregate of grasping of feeling is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.
The aggregate of grasping of perception and the aggregate of grasping of volitional formations are also like this.

The aggregate of grasping of consciousness is included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.

The realm of hell is included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by six consciousnesses. All the latent afflictions of the desire realm increase it.
The realms of animals, hungry ghosts, and humans are also like this.

The realm of gods is included in the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by six consciousnesses. All the latent afflictions of the three realms increase it.ğŸ”½The class of afflictions to be eliminated by seeing suffering is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All those to be eliminated by seeing suffering and the pervasive contaminants to be eliminated by seeing the origin in the three realms increase it.

The class of afflictions to be eliminated by seeing the origin is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All those to be eliminated by seeing the origin and the pervasive contaminants to be eliminated by seeing suffering in the three realms increase it.

The class of afflictions eliminated by seeing cessation is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The universal and specific contaminants of the three realms eliminated by seeing cessation increase it.ğŸ”½The class of afflictions eliminated by seeing the path is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The universal and specific contaminants of the three realms eliminated by seeing the path increase it.

The class of afflictions eliminated by cultivation is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The universal and specific contaminants of the three realms eliminated by cultivation increase it.

Material dharmas are included in eleven realms, eleven sense bases, and one aggregate. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of cessation. They are cognized by six consciousnesses. The universal contaminants and those eliminated by cultivation of the desire and form realms increase them.

Mental factors are categorized as seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. They are discerned by one consciousness. All proclivities increase them.

Mental activities are categorized as one element, one sense base, and three aggregates. They are known by nine knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation. They are discerned by one consciousness. All proclivities increase them.

Factors not associated with the mind are categorized as one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of anotherâ€™s mind. They are discerned by one consciousness. The proclivities of the three realms that have objects to which they are conducive increase them.

Unconditioned factors are categorized as one element and one sense base. They are not included in the aggregates. They are known by six knowledges: the knowledge of the mind that knows anotherâ€™s mind, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause , and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness. The proclivities do not increase them.

The earth element is categorized as one element, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by seven knowledges: the knowledge of the mind that knows anotherâ€™s mind, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path are exceptions. It is discerned by two consciousnesses. The proclivities of the realm of desire and the realm of form that are universally active and those that are eliminated by the path of cultivation increase it.
The water, fire, wind, and space elements are also like this.

The element of consciousness is included in seven elements, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities increase it.ğŸ”½Dharmas to be abandoned by seeing suffering are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities to be abandoned by seeing suffering in the three realms and the pervasive proclivities to be abandoned by seeing the origin increase them.ğŸ”½Dharmas to be abandoned by seeing the origin are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities to be abandoned by seeing the origin in the three realms and the pervasive proclivities to be abandoned by seeing suffering increase them.

Dharmas to be abandoned by seeing cessation are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are cognized by one consciousness. All proclivities to be abandoned by seeing cessation in the three realms and the pervasive proclivities increase them.

Dharmas that are to be eliminated by the path of vision are categorized as three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness. All those that are to be eliminated by the path of vision in the three realms and the universally-occurring contaminants increase in accordance with them.

Dharmas that are to be eliminated by cultivation are categorized as eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by six consciousnesses. All those that are to be eliminated by cultivation in the three realms and the universally-occurring contaminants increase in accordance with them.

Dharmas that are not to be eliminated are categorized as three realms, two sense bases, and five aggregates. They are known by eight knowledges excluding the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the origin. They are discerned by one consciousness. They are not increased by contaminants.ğŸ”½The contaminants of craving for desire and ill-will are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the class, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness. The contaminants that have desire as their object increase in accordance with them.

The contaminants of craving for existence are categorized as one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. They are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of the Dharma, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path. They are discerned by one consciousness. The contaminants that have the realms of form and non-form as their object increase in accordance with them.

The latent tendency of pride is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The latent tendencies of the three realms that have impure objects increase it.

The latent tendency of ignorance is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. Except for ignorance that has pure objects, all other latent tendencies increase it.ğŸ”½The latent tendency of views is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The latent tendencies of the three realms that are eliminated by seeing, that have impure objects, and the ignorance that is associated with views that have pure objects increase it.

The latent tendency of doubt is included in one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate. It is known by eight knowledges except for the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path. It is cognized by one consciousness. The latent tendencies of the three realms that are eliminated by seeing, that have impure objects, and the ignorance that is associated with doubt that has pure objects increase it.

The first abode of consciousness is included in eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates, is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path, is cognized by six consciousnesses, and is increased by all the latent afflictions of the desire realm.ğŸ”½The second abode of consciousness is included in fourteen realms, ten sense bases, and five aggregates, is known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path, is cognized by four consciousnesses, and is increased by all the latent afflictions of the form realm.

The third and fourth abodes of consciousness are included in eleven realms, ten sense bases, and five aggregates, are known by seven knowledges excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by four consciousnesses, and are increased by all the latent afflictions of the form realm.

The fifth, sixth, and seventh abodes of consciousness are included in three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates, are known by six knowledges excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path, are cognized by one consciousness, and are increased by all the latent afflictions of the formless realm.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Compendium of Ascertainments, Fascicle 9
